title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
The US Capitol Police is bracing for an assault on Congress on Thursday after receiving an intelligence warning of a “possible” plot by a militia group two months after supporters of Donald Trump stormed the complex. 

The warning came as leaders in the House of Representatives cancelled plans for Thursday's session, moving all previously scheduled votes to Wednesday evening and clearing the floor of official business for the rest of the week. A vote on sweeping legislation to protect voting rights in America was passed in the lower chamber before the shutdown.

Hundreds of Trump supporters overwhelmed US Capitol Police officers to storm the building and disrupt the certification of Joe Biden's election victory in January.

Tim Ryan, a Democratic congressman from Ohio who chairs the subcommittee overseeing the US Capitol Police, shared intelligence indicating some conspiracy theorists believe March 4 to 6 to be the “true inauguration day”.

Christopher Wray, FBI director, told Congress this week the number of domestic extremist cases being pursued by the bureau had risen “significantly” over the past year.

Coronavirus digest

  • Joe Biden and Democratic leaders reached a compromise deal that would limit who is eligible for $1,400 stimulus cheques.

  • T-cell responses in patients who had been vaccinated or previously infected with Covid-19 were as strong as when faced with virus variants, according to a US study.

  • Nine out of 10 coronavirus deaths have occurred in countries with high obesity levels, according to WHO-backed research.

  • A leading developer of digital Covid passport solutions said a vaccine and testing certification scheme “should not last for ever”.

  • China and South Africa have seized thousands of doses of fake vaccines and made more than 80 arrests.

  • Rishi Sunak delivered a spend now, tax later Budget to drag the UK economy out of the Covid-19 crisis. (FT)

Follow our live coronavirus coverage.

In the news

Blinken disavows ‘costly military interventions' The Biden administration will seek to draw a line under a history of “costly military interventions” and policies aimed at regime change in other countries, according to Antony Blinken. (FT)

Facebook lifts ban on US political advertising The social media group from today will lift a ban on political advertising imposed around the US election to curb the spread of misinformation, and has pledged to investigate whether its political ads systems need a further overhaul. (FT)

Amazon opens first physical store outside North America Amazon has opened a convenience store in west London, its first physical outlet outside of North America. The store is similar to the Amazon Go outlets, which opened three years ago in the US, but branded Amazon Fresh. (FT)

Apollo bets on Las Vegas comeback Las Vegas Sands has agreed to sell the operations and real estate of the Venetian resort and casino for $6.25bn, just over a month after the death of the gambling company's controversial founder, Sheldon Adelson. Apollo, the US private equity group, is set to run the resort on the Las Vegas Strip. (FT)

Insurer Oscar Health falls on Wall Street debut The health insurance company co-founded by Joshua Kushner, Oscar Health, slipped on its first day of trading on Wall Street after raising $1.4bn in an initial public offering. The fall contrasts with big pops in other recent debuts. (FT)

EU-UK tensions flare EU-UK relations have been plunged into a new crisis after Brussels warned that Britain would break international law by taking unilateral steps to ease the impact of Brexit on Northern Irish businesses. (FT)

Calls for diplomatic intervention in Myanmar grow louder The UN said Wednesday was the bloodiest day in Myanmar since last month's overthrow of Aung San Suu Kyi's civilian government after 38 civilians were killed. The UK has requested a UN Security Council meeting on Myanmar on Friday. (FT)

Cuomo apologises after harassment claims but rules out resigning An emotional Andrew Cuomo offered his fullest apology yet for conduct that prompted two women to accuse him of sexual harassment but insisted he would not resign. The apology came as a growing chorus of legislators, including several from his own Democratic party, called for him to step down. (FT)

The day ahead

Jay Powell discusses US economy The Federal Reserve chairman's appearance today at the virtual Wall Street Journal Jobs Summit will be closely followed.

  • US policymakers, from the Federal Reserve to the Biden administration, have lost faith in the unemployment rate as an indicator of the strength of the jobs market. (WSJ, FT)

Brussels aims to toughens pay reporting obligations The European Commission will on Thursday introduce anti-wage discrimination legislation that will require large companies to disclose information on their gender pay gap and give workers the right to demand transparency over their salaries. (FT)

Opec+ meeting Oil producers are set to discuss easing supply curbs as countries recover from Covid-19. (Reuters)

Live Q&A: The FT's next live Business Clinic will explore the likely impact of the UK's Budget measures on business. We invite readers to share comments and questions ahead of the live discussion at 11am UK time. View the discussion here or watch live via the FT's YouTube channel or LinkedIn page. (FT)

What else we're reading

US vs China In the first weeks of his presidency, Joe Biden has been eager to deliver a central message when it comes to China: he will not be a pushover. The administration believes it can craft a much more effective strategy for dealing with Beijing by forging common ground with US allies and partners. (FT)

Biden chooses not to antagonise Mohammed bin Salman The unclassified report into the killing of Jamal Khashoggi has underlined the limits to Joe Biden's commitment to human rights in his foreign policy, writes Katrina Manson. The US's weak response to the report's findings will embolden Iran and may also push the Gulf Arabs, including Saudi Arabia, into a military alliance with Israel against Tehran, argues David Gardner. (FT)

Bitcoin 1.0: the ancient stone money of Yap To better understand bitcoin, a pair of researchers are studying an ancient stone money system that once existed on the Micronesian island of Yap, where local communities would treat large limestone discs as a medium of exchange, writes Gillian Tett. (FT)

Pandemics and the paradox of progress The more humans tip the world into disequilibrium, through deforestation, the destruction of biodiversity and the raising of atmospheric temperatures, the more threat to us pathogens will pose, writes David Pilling. (FT)

Can Eurostar get back on track? If Brexit is a permanent speed bump for the Eurostar, coronavirus is an earthquake. Passenger numbers have fallen 95 per cent on the cross-Channel rail service. Its cathedral-like shed at St Pancras — once the largest enclosed space in the world — now stands almost deserted. (FT)

Reinvention of the in-house lawyer Demand is increasing for in-house lawyers who understand how to use technology to provide companies with better legal strategies and services. Enter the digital general counsel. This is the latest part of our series on how the legal profession is responding to digital transformation. (FT)

Video of the day

Eco-friendly vineyards, the New Zealand way The country's wine industry was the first in the world to have a national sustainability programme and more than 96 per cent of its vineyards operate according to specific environmental standards. One has even managed to reduce its waste to less than that of a typical domestic household. (FT)
